awd_titl_txt: IRES: U.S.-India Collaborative Research in Mechanical, Biomedical, and Materials Science Engineering for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical Description 
IRES: The US-India Collaborative Research in Mechanical, Biomedical, and Materials Science Engineering for Undergraduates is a joint research project between Ohio State and Colorado State Universities, and the Jaipur Engineering College and Research Centre in India. US-students will conduct research on a prosthetic device that was pioneered several decades ago at the Dr. P.K. Sethi Rehabilitation and Jaipur Limb Training Centre. It continues to be used throughout India due to the low-cost, cultural appropriateness, and magnitude of the amputee population. At present, the number of amputees in the world is significant, particularly in the developing countries. 
          
This IRES project will provide internships for five talented US-undergraduate engineering students each year over three years to conduct research and development activities that will provide a thorough understanding of this prosthetic device. At present, little is known about the properties of the individual components that comprise the device. The goal of this research is to improve the product for wider distribution within India and for eventual mass production so that it?s potential for relieving the suffering of amputees in the developing world and beyond may be realized. 

Broader Description
This project will make significant advances in prosthetic devices for the developing world. Although much is known in the U.S. regarding prosthetic devices, understanding the various design and production constraints for developing countries is less well-known. The project evaluation will lead to a better understanding of the impact of humanitarian projects on the development of engineering students. The research has the potential to transform the way that prosthetic devices are made in non-western regions in the world.

The benefit to society accrued through this project is significant. Researchers will target women and underrepresented students for participation, encouraging them to pursue advanced degrees in engineering. This will serve to broaden participation in STEM fields. The results will be broadly disseminated through a variety of journals and conference venues. The impact on the World?s poor who are amputees is potentially significant.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project brought together Ohio State University, Colorado State University, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, and Jaipur Santokba Durlabhji Memorial Hospital, Jaipur. Students from US institutions were sent to India for a summer research project related to development and improvement of the Jaipur Foot. This has provided a unique opportunity for a group of students to engage in engineering from a global perspective. Not only did the students getnhands on experience, they were engaged in practicing engineering across cultural boundaries. In addition, there is a great need for a low-cost and reliable prosthetic device around the world. Through the research conducted during this project we have identified a means by which the Jaipur Foot could be mass-produced.

Both the biomechanics community as well as the engineering education field have been impacted by this work. The students conducted basic level mechanical analysis of the components of the Jaipur foot- something that has not been done in the last 40+ years. This provided baseline information about material behavior that will shape future decisions about mass production of the foot. The students have made a finite element model of the foot that can be used for years to come to guide design changes/alterations. Lastly, the health care industry will ultimately be affected by the data generated as part of this research. Not only in India, but likely in other parts of the world, low-cost prosthetic foot design will benefit from the prospective outcomes of these studies.  

The experiences created for the US students, and their Indian hosts (including students and faculty) will impact personal lives of all and may directly affect their future efforts/careers. Learning to work and live in another country enabled these US students to grow and adapt in their future lives and careers. The skills they learned are a lifelong lesson. Additionally, the host institution has faculty and graduate students who have been working with the US students, this is likely affecting their cultural and technical skills as well. It is the first time they have worked directly with colleagues from the US. Beyond sharing science and technology, the personal skills and development are outreaching.

With the development of a better, low-cost prosthetic foot, millions of lives will be improved in India and other poverty-stricken countries. The Jaipur foot has been in production for many years- with little to no research development. Through the research conducted as part of this project, millions of poverty stricken people will benefit and have a better life as a result of design improvements to this foot. 

Through participation in this project, all students learned valuable skills as researchers, collaborators, and scholars.  They were fully engaged in the project and were required to be self-reliant in order to perform their duties while in-country.  Several of the student researchers have indicated an interest in pursuing further graduate studies upon completion of their undergraduate degrees.  We believe that this project has provided them with an excellent background in conducting research as well as an excellent foundation for understanding multi-cultural issues.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2018
Modified by: Tammy L Haut Donahue
